Graphical abstract The unique 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 with high conductivity and rich active sites is prepared through recovery of Co from spent LIBs, exhibiting enhanced catalyzed water splitting performance. Along with the continuous consumption in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), the price of cobalt is inevitably going up in recent years. Therefore, recycling valuable Co element from spent devices, and boosting its service efficiency are becoming two indispensable approaches to promote the utilization of Co in various energy conversion/storage devices. Herein, we realize the recovery of Co from spent LIBs and synthesize a three–dimensional (3D) sea-urchin-like cobalt nitride composite material (labeled as CoN-Gr-2), which is used as a bi-functional catalyst for water splitting. Benefiting from the intrinsic high conductivity, larger surface area and unique 3D sea–urchin–like architecture, CoN-Gr-2 shows an excellent electron transfer efficiency, highly exposed active sites as well as the superior mass transport capacity. The CoN-Gr-2 catalyst exhibits low overpotentials of 128.9 mV and 280 mV for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which are comparable to the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C and RuO2 catalysts. Moreover, when adopting CoN-Gr-2 as both anode and cathode materials for overall water splitting (in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte), the assembled cell achieves a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 1.61 V, which almost close to that of Pt/C||RuO2 benchmark (1.60 V), demonstrating its superior water-splitting efficiency. Meanwhile, the CoN catalysts exhibit strong chemical interaction with the Gr support, suppressing the aggregation of CoN catalysts and maintains their high activity during HER and OER reactions. So, the cell exhibits a high current retention of 97.3% after 40 h. This work successfully develops an industrial chain from recycling Co wastes in spent energy devices to controllably designing 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr with high water splitting efficiency. Therefore, it could further promote the efficient utilization of valuable Co element in various energy devices. Keywords Recycling valuable Co element Three-dimensional (3D) sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr Highly exposed active sites Water splitting 1 Introduction Over the past decade, in order to satisfy the demand of the human society development, the overuses of fossil fuels have seriously led to global energy crisis and environmental issues, which may restrict the further sustainable development of human society. Therefore, the gradual transition from fossil fuels consuming economy to the clean energy model is urgently required [1]. Recently, tremendous efforts have been focused on searching the substitutions of the traditional fossil fuels [2]. Hydrogen (H2), as a green energy carrier has been considered as one of the most promising candidates to substitute the fossil fuels due to its high energy density [3]. Among various H2 production processes, water splitting through the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) polarization processes has been recognized as the most efficient and green way. Nevertheless, the sluggish electrochemical kinetics of OER and HER catalytic processes result in low energy conversion efficiency, and thus still hinder the practical application of water electrolysis. To date, the state-of-the-art HER and OER catalysts have been respectively identified as Pt-based nanocatalysts and Ru/Ir-based noble metal oxides [4]. However, these precious metals have extremely restricted their commercialization in water splitting industry, owing to their high cost. Hence, it is highly desirable to construct high-efficiency, cost-effective and durable HER/OER electrocatalysts based on earth-abundant elements. As the potential alternatives of noble metals based HER/OER electrocatalysts in water splitting, transition metal cobalt (Co) based oxides, oxyhydroxides, selenides, borides, phosphides, nitrides and carbonaceous hybrids have been widely reported due to their advantages in electrocatalytic activities [5-15]. Among these Co-based HER/OER catalysts, both experimental and theoretical calculation have demonstrated that cobalt nitride (CoN) is an effective HER/OER electrocatalyst owing to their internally superior water dissociation kinetics, fairly low electric resistance and excellent resistant ability toward corrosion [16-23]. In spite of the various advantages of Co-based catalysts in HER/OER, the continuous consumption of Co source in LIBs causes its price to rise rapidly. Moerover, along with the increased usage of Co in various energy conversion and storage devices, its price will continuously go up [24,25]. Consequently, the industrial or commercial application of Co-based catalysts will be suffered from the high cost of Co. Therefore, recycling the valuable Co from spent devices and meanwhile boosting its service efficiency (for example decreasing the particle sizes, and building hierarchically porous architectures) [12,26,27] will be two promising strategies to realize the maximum utilization of Co source and support its application in various energy conversion/storage devices. In this work, we, for the first time, recycled Co as cobalt oxalates from the spent LIBs (Model number: BL-5CA) through the typical pre-treatment, washing, filtration, calcination, leaching and re-filtration processes. Using the as-reclaimed cobalt oxalates as Co sources, we have successfully designed a new class of strongly coupled cobalt nitride-graphene (defined as CoN-Gr) hybrid catalyst, through the treatment of Co based hybrid precursors in NH3 atmosphere at 400 °C. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , as prepared CoN-Gr-2 catalyst displays a unique 3D sea-urchin-like structure. The CoN nanoparticles are well-protected with Gr, which can prevent the agglomeration of CoN nanoparticles, and thus provides abundant active sites for electrocatalytic reaction. Moreover, the voids among the Gr sheets provides abundant channels for facilitating mass transfer. Simultaneously, both CoN and Gr have excellent electric conductivities, thereby resulting of CoN-Gr-2 catalyst possesses an excellent electron conductivity. Benefiting from the high active catalytic activity of CoN, abundant active sites, high electronic conductivity as well as fast mass transfer, excellent electrocatalytic performance in water splitting could be expected. When the prepared CoN-Gr-2 as both cathode and anode electrocatalysts for full water splitting, the (–) CoN-Gr-2||CoN-Gr-2 (+) system just required a cell voltage of 1.61 V to drive a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is comparable to that of (–) Pt/C||RuO2 (+) benchmark (1.60 V). This advance may boost the development of Co metal based electrocatalysts and their application in HER/OER electrocatalysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents The graphene oxide (GO) used in this work was synthesized from graphite particles by Hummer’s method [28]. Spent LIBs (BL-5CA; LiCoO2 is cathode material in which) were utilized for recovery cobalt element. Other materials used herein: N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP), glycine, ascorbic acid, oxalic acid, cobalt oxalate, Nafion solution (5 wt%), NH3·H2O and KOH were purchased from Aladdin. all reagents used in this paper were analytical grade. 2.2 Recovery of cobalt oxalate from spent LIBs The recovery of cobalt oxalate from spent LIBs was accomplished using Pai’s method [29]. Including the following processes: the pre–treatment of spent LIBs (i.e. discharging, dismantling, separating and crushing), ultrasonic washing of cathode with NPM, filtration of resultant products, the calcination of products at 700 °C, the leaching of LiCoO2 by mild organic acids (glycine & ascorbic acid) at 80 °C, secondary filtration, adding oxalic acid to precipitate Co(II) as cobalt oxalate. 2.3 Synthesis of Gr, bulky CoN, and a series of CoN-Gr hybrid nanomaterials As shown in Scheme 1, for the synthesis of Gr, bulky CoN, and a series of CoN-Gr hybrid nanomaterials, the precursors were firstly dissolved in 40 mL distilled water and implemented the hydrothermal processes in 60 mL Teflon-lined autoclaves at 120 °C for 12 h. Then, the filtered products were dried in a vacuum at 80 °C, placed in a porcelain boat in the tube and heated at 400 °C in the NH3 atmosphere for 2 h (the heating rate is 5 °C min−1). The precursor solutions of different control samples were conducted as follows: (1) For the Gr matrix: 150 mg of GO and 5 mL of NH3·H2O were dissolved in 40.0 mL H2O under stirring for 6 h. (2) For the CoN-Gr-1 matrix: 150 mg of GO, 183 mg of cobalt oxalate and 5 mL of NH3·H2O were utilized. (3) For the CoN-Gr-2 matrix: 150 mg of GO, 366 mg of cobalt oxalate and 5 mL of NH3·H2O were utilized. (4) For the CoN-Gr-3 matrix: 150 mg of GO, 549 mg of cobalt oxalate and 5 mL of NH3·H2O were utilized. (5) For the bulky CoN: 732 mg of cobalt oxalate and 5 mL of NH3·H2O were utilized. 2.4 Physical characterization and electrochemical measurements The detailed physical characterization and electrochemical measurements are provided in Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out to analyze the crystal structure of each control sample. As shown in Fig. 1 , the XRD pattern of the Gr matrix shows a strong peak located at 2θ = 26.5° and a weak peak located at 2θ = 44.5°, while the characteristic peak located at 2θ = 12° for GO disappears (as shown in Fig. S1), indicating the reduction of GO to Gr during NH3 treatment. The peaks in XRD patterns of CoN-Gr-1 and CoN-Gr-2 are ascribed to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110) and (103) diffraction planes of Co3N (JCPDS CARD No, 06–0691), suggesting the formation of Co3N during NH3 treatment. For CoN-Gr-3 and bulky CoN, the Co species is determined to be Co5.47N (JCPDS CARD No, 41–0943). The XRD patterns of bulky CoN and CoN-Gr materials prove that Co precursors have successfully transformed into the metal nitrides, no characteristic peaks of byproducts can be observed. However, compared with CoN-Gr-3 and CoN, more N atoms were doped into the crystal textures of CoN-Gr-1 and CoN-Gr-2. The morphological characteristics of different control samples were explored by scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM). The SEM image of Gr (Fig. 2 a1) exhibits the typical 2D nanosheets with abundant corrugations and ripples. TEM image (Fig. 2a2) further proves the 2D nanosheets of Gr matrix. Meanwhile, the high-magnification TEM image of lateral part (inset of Fig. 2a2) indicates that the Gr matrix is stacked by many Gr layers (more than 20 layers). SEM image (Fig. 2b1 and TEM image Fig. 2b2) reveals that pure CoN is a bulk material stacking with primary Co5.47N nanoparticles. Despite the potential electrolytic activity of Co5.47N, the electrocatalytic performance is still limited by the its insufficient surface area because of large particle size over 200 nm. When coupled with Gr, as shown in Fig. S3, the size of Co2N0.67 particles in CoN-Gr-1 are dramatically reduced to average 7.3 nm (Fig. S2a1, S2a2 and S3a), which can be expected to improve the electrocatalytic performance due to more active sizes. The reduced particle size can be attributed to the strong interaction between Gr and Co2N0.67 nanoparticles, thus preventing the agglomeration of Co2N0.67. Equally importantly, the Gr also acts as a good electronic support to facilitate electron transport. With this considering, coupling the Co2N0.67 catalyst with Gr has the potential to further improve the electrocatalytic performance in water splitting. It should be noted that the catalyst loading is another important factor that has a great impact on the electrocatalytic performance. In this regard, the Co2N0.67 catalyst was doubled based on CoN-Gr-1 and obtained CoN-Gr-2 catalyst. As displayed in Fig. 2c1–c2 and 2d–j, the Co2N0.67 particles (confirmed by Co2N0.67 (101) plane with lattice distance of 0.204 nm in Fig. 2f) in CoN-Gr-2 show the similar size distribution compared with that of CoN-Gr-2, where the particle size still maintains at the level of less than 10 nm. Under this condition, the raised catalyst loading means the improved active sites for catalytic reactions. Moreover, CoN-Gr-2 catalyst also displays a sea-urchin-like morphology with abundant 3D hierarchically porous channels, which is beneficial for facilitating mass transfer and accelerate electrocatalytic reactions. Further increasing the catalyst loading, the Gr is insufficient to hinder the agglomeration process. As shown in Fig. S2b1 and S2b2, the particle size increases to over 50 nm, even some particles display sizes of over 500 nm. The large particle size results in incompletely ammoniated process, the catalyst exists as Co5.47N (as same as pure CoN sample) instead of Co2N0.67. Additionally, it is observed that the 3D sea-urchin-like morphology is also disappeared in CoN-Gr-3, which will block the mass transfer to some extent. In this regard, the enlarged particle size and blocked mass transfer channels will affect the electrocatalytic effect. The EDS line-scan analysis was showed in inset of Fig. 3 a for a single Co2N0.67 nanoparticle across the radial direction, which was implemented for observing the elemental intensities of C, Co and N as well (Fig. 3a–d). As displayed in Fig. 3b, in the particle region (between 5 and 16 nm), the C content is lower than the areas surrounding particle region (<5 nm and > 16 nm across the radial direction). In contrast, both Co and N show the opposite trends (Fig. 3c–d) and no other elements are detected. Combining the HR–TEM images and elemental mappings in Fig. 2f–j, proving the successful synthesis of pure Co2N0.67 nanoparticles. The aforementioned characterizations suggested that the appropriate ratio of Co/Gr in the precursor solution is crucial for constructing the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 with abundant hierarchically porous channels and well–dispersed nano–sized catalyst. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and corresponding pore-size distribution analysis were recorded for probing the specific surface areas and pore distribution of as-prepared samples (Fig. 4 a–e). The corresponding pore size distribution plots for adsorption data, based on the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method are showed in the insets of Fig. 4a–e. Benefitting from the unique 3D sea–urchin–like architecture, CoN-Gr-2 possesses both mesopores in the range of 2–30 nm and macropores over 50 nm. Due to the similar structure, CoN-Gr-1 shows the similar pore distribution but with less pores. In contrast, for other samples such as CoN and CoN-Gr-3, they display wide pore size distribution and belong to macropores. The Gr matrix only shows a narrow pore size distribution in the range of 3–20 nm, corresponding to the stacking pores of Gr nanosheets. Attributing to the abundant meso- and macropore distribution, the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 owns a larger specific surface area (108.42 m2g−1) compared with those of Gr (34.79 m2 g−1), CoN-Gr-1 (60.26 m2 g−1), CoN-Gr-3 (54.87 m2 g−1) and pure CoN (20.62 m2 g−1). The abundant meso- and macro-pores in CoN-Gr-2 can be acted as mass transfer channels to promote the electrocatalytic reactions. We further collected the Raman spectra of Gr and CoN-Gr-2. As shown in Fig. 4f, the two main peaks located at approximately 1356 and 1592 cm−1 for Gr and CoN-Gr-2, belong to the D-band and G-band, respectively. In general, the area ratio of D-band to G-band (I D/I G) can disclose the defect level of carbonaceous nanomaterials. CoN-Gr-2 shows a larger I D/I G value of 1.52 than that of Gr matrix (1.19), which indicates that the 3D sea-urchin-like architecture and the tiny Co2N0.67 nanoparticles embedded into Gr layers indeed boost the separation of Gr layers and meantime afford more carbon edges. In conclusion, benefitting from the synergistic effect of tiny Co2N0.67 nanoparticles tightly coupled on Gr and the 3D hierarchically porous architectures, the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 possesses a larger specific surface area and more meso/macroporous channels. The unique structure endows the sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 with more active sites and fast mass transfer as well. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Fig. 5 a) indicates that the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 mainly consists of C, O, N and Co elements. As revealed in the high-resolution C1s XPS spectrum (Fig. 5b), the as-fitted peaks located at ~ 284.3, 285.3 and 288.4 eV are corresponding to the C-Co bonds [30], C–C (sp 2) bonds and C-O bonds, respectively. The appearing of abundant C-Co bonds confirms that most CoN nanoparticles are chemically bonded on Gr layers via the C-Co bonds. It is further confirmed by the high–resolution Co 2p 3/2 XPS spectrum (Fig. 5e), where the Co-C bond at ~ 779.4 eV is also detected [31]. In the O 1 s and N 1 s (Fig. 5b–c), only C-OH, C = O and Co-N species are observed, which can be assigned to the oxygen groups from Gr and Co2N0.67 [19]. In this regard, we can conclud that the strong chemical interaction between Gr and Co2N0.67, which inhabits the agglomeration of catalyst, thus endowing the CoN-Gr-2 with more active sites. To investigate the bifunctional electrocatalytic performances of as-synthesized catalysts toward full water splitting, the HER catalytic activities of Gr, CoN-Gr and bulky CoN were first explored in 1.0 M KOH. As showed in Fig. 6 a, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves reveal that CoN-Gr-2 exhibits the best HER catalytic efficiency among all control catalysts, which is even comparable to the state-of-the-art HER catalyst (20 wt% Pt/C). In detail, as showed in Fig. 6b, the onset overpotential (η onset) and overpotentials at 10 mA cm−2 (η 10) for CoN-Gr-2 are just 37.5 and 128.9 mV, which are much smaller than those of Gr matrix (536.4 and 720.7 mV), CoN-Gr-1 (365.8 and 448.6 mV), CoN-Gr-3 (85.1 and 195.9 mV) and bulky CoN (159.2 and 331.6 mV), respectively. Simultaneously, both the η onset and η 10 of CoN-Gr-2 are only 23.2 mV and 61.5 mV larger than that of 20 wt% Pt/C (η onset = 14.3 mV and η 10 = 67.4 mV). Remarkably, as compared in Table S1, the optimal CoN-Gr-2 delivers an extremely lower η 10 value than the most of previous reported high-performance HER catalysts except the Co4N@NC (η 10 = 62 mV) [30], CoN@VON (η 10 = 97 mV) [32], Co3O4–Co4N (η 10 = 90 mV) [33] and CoP-OMC (η 10 = 90 mV) [9]. Meantime, the Tafel slope of CoN-Gr-2 (67.35 mV dec–1) is much lower than those of Gr (149.52 mV dec–1), CoN-Gr-1 (117.29 mV dec–1), CoN-Gr-3 (78.89 mV dec–1) and bulky CoN (85.46 mV dec–1), respectively (Fig. 6c); indicating higher HER kinetics of CoN-Gr-2. It is well known that the corresponding Tafel slopes for the Tafel-, Heyrovsky- and Volmer-determined HER are 29.5, 39 or 118 mV dec-1, respectively, under the alkaline condition [34]. In the case of CoN-Gr-2, the Tafel slope is 67.35 mV dec-1), which follows a Volmer-Heyrovsky reaction mechanism (i.e. electrochemical desorption is the rate-determining step). As compared in Table S1, the optimal CoN-Gr-2 catalyst delivers an extremely low Tafel slope, which is superior to most of previous reported CoN based high-performance HER catalysts except the Co4N@NC (Tafel slope = 37 mV dec-1) [30] and Co3O4-Co4N (Tafel slope = 57.8 mV dec-1) [33]. The low Tafel slope also indicates that CoN-Gr-2 owns the Pt-like HER catalytic efficiency. Moreover, the DFT calculation results have proved that Co sites near the N atoms are the active centers in CoN catalysts [16]. The exact Co contents of CoN-Gr and bulky CoN catalysts are evaluated through the coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry ICP technique. 200 mg of samples were first calcined in the oxygen atmosphere; then, the products were dissolved in 100 mL H2SO4 solution. As a result, the amounts of Co elements in the hybrid sample were determined to be 34.68 wt%, 54.80 wt%, and 64.46 wt% for CoN-Gr-1, CoN-Gr-2, and CoN-Gr-3, respectively (as displayed in Table S2). The amounts of Co elements in 1 mg samples (mmol) were determined to be 5.448 × 10-3, 8.608 × 10-3, 1.046 × 10-2, and 1.623 × 10-2 for CoN-Gr-1, CoN-Gr-2, CoN-Gr-3, and CoN respectively (as displayed in Table S2). Thus, assuming all Co atoms in catalysts tested by ICP-OES (as shown in Table S2) are active toward HER catalysis, the turnover frequency (TOF) values between −0.60 and + 0.20 V vs. RHE are calculated in Fig. S5. When overpotential is 400 mV, the CoN-Gr-2 displays a much larger TOF value (0.13 s−1) than those of CoN-Gr-3 (0.07 s−1), CoN (0.01 s−1) and CoN-Gr-1 (0.005 s−1), suggesting the highest average efficiency of Co atoms in CoN-Gr-2 and meanwhile indicating the high intrinsic activity of CoN-Gr-2 toward HER. The electrochemical specific active area (ECSA) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were further carried out to explore the origin of high HER catalytic activity for CoN-Gr-2. We first measured the electrochemical double layer capacitances (C dl) of all CoN-Gr and bulky CoN control catalysts using the CV method in 1.0 M KOH (Fig. S6). As displayed in Fig. 6d, the Cdl value calculated at + 0.22 V vs. RHE for CoN-Gr-2 (15.6 mF cm−2) is much larger than those of CoN-Gr-1 (2.0 mF cm−2), CoN-Gr-3 (4.2 mF cm−2) and bulky CoN (3.3 mF cm−2). As the C dl values are in proportion to the ECSA, the C dl results prove that the 3D sea–urchin–like architecture of CoN-Gr-2 indeed boost exposing more electrochemically active sites toward HER catalysis. The EIS Nyquist plots at −0.30 V vs. RHE of all CoN control catalysts were also measured to investigate the different HER kinetics (Fig. 6e). All EIS Nyquist plots are fitted using the equivalent circuit model in inset of Fig. 6e. The semi-circle at high-frequency corresponds to charge transfer resistance (R ct). The R ct (i.e. R 2;) values fitted from the high frequency semicircles are the typical responses for charge–transfer processes and R p (i.e. R 3; mass transfer resistance of the adsorbed intermediates) values fitted from the low frequency semicircles are connected to the adsorption processes on electrode surfaces [15]. The bulky CoN possesses the largest R ct (33.13 Ω) among all CoN-Gr control catalysts [CoN-Gr-1 (19.25 Ω), CoN-Gr-2 (19.72 Ω) and CoN-Gr-3 (20.4 Ω)]. Nevertheless, these CoN-Gr control catalysts exhibit similar R ct values, demonstrating the similar charge transfer efficiency of three CoN-Gr catalysts. Especially, among four control samples, CoN-Gr-1 displays the smallest R ct value but the worst HER catalytic efficiency. In other words, the electroconductibility is not the crucial factor controlling the HER catalytic activities of different CoN-Gr catalysts. On the other hand, the R p values decrease by the order of CoN-Gr-1 (352.1 Ω) > bulky CoN (64.48 Ω) > CoN-Gr-3 (51.87 Ω) > CoN-Gr-2 (25.254 Ω), demonstrating the best mass transfer efficiency of the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2. Here to, the fairly high HER catalytic activity of CoN-Gr-2 presumably dues to its unique 3D sea-urchin-like structure enables faster mass-transfer. We further evaluated the HER catalytic stability of the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 and 20 wt% Pt/C at −0.2 V vs. RHE (Fig. 6f). After 10 h of polarization test, 97.15 % of initial current response is maintained for the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2. Whereas, only 91.24 % of initial current response is kept for 20 wt% Pt/C. For demonstrating the possible applications of as–prepared CoN-Gr composites in overall water splitting, their OER catalytic performances have also been measured and evaluated. As shown in Fig. 7 a, b, CoN-Gr-2 possesses the superior OER catalytic activity with the smallest η 10 value of 280 mV compared with those of Gr (620 mV), CoN-Gr-1 (390 mV), CoN-Gr-3 (310 mV) and bulky CoN (350 mV). Especially, the η 10 value of CoN-Gr-2 (280 mV) is even 10 mV smaller than that of the state-of-the-art RuO2 OER catalyst (η 10 = 290 mV) and some previously reported Co-based electrocatalysts (Table S3). Meantime, as shown in Fig. 7c, although the Tafel slope of CoN-Gr-2 catalyst (68.83 mV dec-1) is slightly larger than that of RuO2 (42.43 mV dec–1), which is much smaller than those of Gr (127.95 mV dec-1), CoN-Gr-1 (113.88 mV dec-1), CoN-Gr-3 (82.36 mV dec-1), bulky CoN (93.87 mV dec-1) and most previously reported Co-based electrocatalysts (Table S3), indicating that CoN-Gr-2 has better OER kinetics. Assuming all Co atoms in CoN-Gr or bulky CoN catalysts (tested by ICP-OES; as shown in Table S2) are active toward OER catalysis, the turnover frequency (TOF) values of OER between 1.20 and 1.80 V vs. RHE are calculated in Fig. S7. At a potential value of 1.65 V vs. RHE, the CoN-Gr-2 displays a much larger TOF value (0.038 s−1) than those of CoN-Gr-3 (0.022 s−1), CoN (0.012 s−1) and CoN-Gr-1 (0.01 s−1), suggesting the highest average efficiency of Co atoms in CoN-Gr-2 and meanwhile indicating the high intrinsic activity of CoN-Gr-2 toward OER. In order to further explore the possible origin for the high OER catalytic performance of CoN-Gr-2, the ECSA and EIS of all control catalysts were measured and evaluated. In order to estimate the ECSA values of CoN-Gr and bulky CoN, their C dl values (which are in proportion to ECSA values) are measured by deriving from the CV curves versus the scan rates between 1.34 and 1.44 V vs. RHE (Fig. S8). As showed in Fig. 7d, at 1.44 V vs. RHE, CoN-Gr-2 displays a much larger C dl value (649.6 mF cm−2) than those of CoN-Gr-1 (95.3 mF cm−2), CoN-Gr-3 (312.5 mF cm−2) and bulky CoN (211.9 mF cm−2), suggesting that CoN-Gr-2 has more exposed active sites for electrocatalysis during OER. EIS spectra recorded at 1.60 V vs. RHE have been carried out to explore more information refer to OER mechanism of each control sample (Fig. 7e). All resultant EIS Nyquist plots are also fitted using the equivalent circuit model in inset of Fig. 7e. The bulky CoN possesses the largest R ct among all control catalysts. CoN-Gr-1 (13.09 Ω) and CoN-Gr-2 (13.95 Ω) nevertheless exhibit smaller R ct values than those of CoN-Gr-3 (16.69 Ω) and CoN (24.49 Ω), demonstrating that the Gr matrixes indeed boost the charge transfer efficiencies of CoN-Gr catalysts. Among four control samples, CoN-Gr-1 has the smallest R ct value but the worst OER catalytic efficiency. In other words, the electroconductibility is not the crucial factor that dominates OER catalytic activities of different control catalysts. On the other hand, the R p values decrease by the order of CoN-Gr-1 (132.81 Ω) > bulky CoN (63.44 Ω) > CoN-Gr-3 (43.89 Ω) > CoN-Gr-2 (6.51 Ω), demonstrating the best mass transfer efficiency of CoN-Gr-2 in OER catalysis. On the whole, the absolutely excellent OER catalytic activity of CoN-Gr-2 presumably due to the unique 3D sea-urchin-like structure that enables faster mass-transfer. We also evaluated OER catalytic stabilities of the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 and RuO2 at 1.60 V vs. RHE (Fig. 7f). After 10 h of polarization measurement, 97.58 % of initial current response is maintained for the strongly coupled 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2; whereas, only 94.35 % of initial current response is kept for RuO2. Considering the outstanding HER/OER catalytic performances of CoN-Gr-2 in alkaline media, the two-electrode electrolyzer using CoN-Gr-2 as both anode and cathode materials was assembled to detect its bifunctional utilization in full water splitting (inset of Fig. 8 a). As can be seen in Fig. 8a, to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the (–) CoN-Gr-2||CoN-Gr-2 (+) cell just needs a cell voltage of 1.61 V, which is comparable to that of (–) 20 wt% Pt/C||RuO2 (+) cell (1.60 V) under the same test conditions. In fact, this value is just 20 mV larger than those of CoN@CC||CoN@CC (1.59 V) [35], FeOOH@Co4N||FeOOH@Co4N (1.59 V) [36] and Ni3N/CMFs/Ni3N||Ni3N/CMFs/Ni3N (1.59) [36]; meanwhile, it is much lower than most as–reported full water splitting cells (Table S4), such as: CoN@VON||CoN@VON (1.64 V) [32], Co5.47N NP@N-PC||Co5.47N NP@N-PC (1.62 V) [17], and CoO-Co4N||CoO-Co4N (1.79 V) [37]. Interestingly, when the cell voltages raise to over 1.68 V, the polarization j values of (–) CoN-Gr-2||CoN-Gr-2 (+) benchmark surpass those of (–) 20 wt% Pt/C||RuO2 (+) cell. More importantly, as displayed in Fig. 8b, after 40 h of water electrolysis at 1.68 V, the (–) CoN-Gr-2||CoN-Gr-2 (+) cell retains 97.3% of the initial current value, which is superior to (–) 20 wt% Pt/C||RuO2 (+) cell (90.8%), demonstrating the outstanding stability of CoN-Gr-2 in full water splitting. To understand the excellent HER/OER catalytic activities and superior durability of CoN-Gr-2, the HAADF-STEM, TEM and XPS characterizations of post-HER CoN-Gr-2 (collected at cathode after 40 h of water electrolysis) and post-OER CoN-Gr-2 (collected at anode after 40 h of water electrolysis) were implemented. For the post-HER CoN-Gr-2, it is found that CoN nanoparticles are tightly coupled on Gr matrixes and no catalyst aggregation and structural change according to the TEM images (Fig. S9a and Fig. 8c) and XPS results (Fig. 8d and Fig. S10). In other words, the catalysts maintain their high catalytic activity during HER reaction. At the cathode side, after 40 h of OER polarization, it is found that a coating layer produced on the surface of CoN particles and formed a core–shell structure. (Fig. 8e) To clarify its components, the post–OER CoN-Gr-2 is also studied by XPS. The results showed that a new phase appears at ~ 780.8 eV in Co 2p3/2 spectrum and ~ 530 eV in O 1 s spectrum, while no obvious change is detected in N1s spectrum, which can be assigned to the CoOOH and CoO x because of the oxidization of CoN under O2/H2O environment (Fig. 8f, Fig. S11 and Fig. S12) [15,17]. On one hand, the formation of CoOOH/CoO x works as a protective layer that hinders the aggregation of CoN nanoparticles. More importantly, the structure of CoOOH/CoO x @CoN has also been proved its high activity in OER reaction [16,38]. As shown in the high-resolution C 1 s and O 1 s spectra, in addition to the oxygen-containing functional groups of O-C = O and C-OH found in the initial CoN-Gr-2 (Fig. 5b and c), these can act as extra active sites for OER. The high-resolution N 1 s XPS spectrum (Fig. 5d) indicates that most Co-N bonds in CoN and pyridinic N bonds doped in the CoN-Gr-2 were preserved, even after enduring strong electrolysis processes. Additional high-valence Co can be found in the post–OER CoN-Gr-2 (Fig. 8f); this may be due to the oxidation of Co atoms into the OER active sites of CoOOH. After the oxidation, the as-formed CoOOH can be further oxidized into CoOOO*, leading to O2 evolution/CoOOH regeneration [15]. Meanwhile, CoN-Gr-2 was a good catalyst for the adsorption and recombination of H intermediates. Thus, the constructed 3D sea-urchin-like structured CoN-Gr-2 with hierarchically porous architectures could offer an abundance of accessible active sites for the alkaline HER. Additionally, the direct growth of Co nitride nanoparticles with metal-like electrical conductivity on the Gr substrate endowed the catalyst with good electron transfer property. Benefiting from these attributes, the 3D sea-urchin-like structured CoN-Gr-2 catalyst exhibited extraordinarily high activity and good stability toward the alkaline HER [39]. With this in mind, the well-maintained structure and catalytic activity at both anode and cathode side attributes to the high durability of (–) CoN-Gr-2||CoN-Gr-2 (+) cell. Generally, the following characteristics of 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 attribute to the excellent OER/HER performance. (1) The intrinsic high conductivity of CoN and Gr boost the electron transfer of CoN-Gr-2 during HER/OER catalysis; (2) The synergistic effects between Gr layers and tiny CoN nanoparticles endows the 3D sea-urchin-like structure with hierarchically porous architectures and abundant mass transport channels for fast mass–transfer. (3) The nanosized CoN (~8.6 nm) provides a large number of active centers for catalytic reactions. (4) The strong chemical interaction between the CoN nanoparticles and Gr prevents the aggregation of catalyst during HER/OER reaction, which results in excellent durability of catalysts and high current retention. 4 Conclusion In summarize, we have successfully recycled Co from the spent LIBs through a simple and environmentally friendly hydrometallurgical route. A series of Gr-CoN composite materials are successfully synthesized and act as bi-functional catalysts for both OER and HER reactions. Among them, the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 shows the highest OER and HER catalytic efficiency, due to the fast mass transport in the hierarchical channels and abundant active centers provided by well-confined nanosized Co2N0.67 catalyst (~8.6 nm). Under a high current density of 10 mA cm−2, the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr-2 delivered low overpotential of 128.9 and 280 mV for HER and OER, respectively, which are comparable to the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C and RuO2 catalysts. More importantly, in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, the (–)CoN-Gr-2||CoN-Gr-2 (+) cell achieves a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 1.61 V for overall water splitting, which is almost near that of Pt/C||RuO2 benchmark (1.6 V), demonstrating its superior water-splitting efficiency. Meanwhile, the cell demonstrates an excellent durability with a high current retention of 97.3% after 40 h, because the strong chemical interaction between CoN and Gr retrains the catalyst aggregation effectively during HER/OER reactions. This work successfully develops an industrial chain from recycling valuable Co element in spent energy devices to building the 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr catalyst with high water splitting efficiency, which could further promote the efficient utilization of valuable element Co in various energy devices. coredata.dc:description: Along with the continuous consumption in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), the price of cobalt is inevitably going up in recent years. Therefore, recycling valuable Co element from spent devices, and boosting its service efficiency are becoming two indispensable approaches to promote the utilization of Co in various energy conversion/storage devices. Herein, we realize the recovery of Co from spent LIBs and synthesize a three–dimensional (3D) sea-urchin-like cobalt nitride composite material (labeled as CoN-Gr-2), which is used as a bi-functional catalyst for water splitting. Benefiting from the intrinsic high conductivity, larger surface area and unique 3D sea–urchin–like architecture, CoN-Gr-2 shows an excellent electron transfer efficiency, highly exposed active sites as well as the superior mass transport capacity. The CoN-Gr-2 catalyst exhibits low overpotentials of 128.9 mV and 280 mV for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which are comparable to the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C and RuO2 catalysts. Moreover, when adopting CoN-Gr-2 as both anode and cathode materials for overall water splitting (in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte), the assembled cell achieves a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 1.61 V, which almost close to that of Pt/C||RuO2 benchmark (1.60 V), demonstrating its superior water-splitting efficiency. Meanwhile, the CoN catalysts exhibit strong chemical interaction with the Gr support, suppressing the aggregation of CoN catalysts and maintains their high activity during HER and OER reactions. So, the cell exhibits a high current retention of 97.3% after 40 h. This work successfully develops an industrial chain from recycling Co wastes in spent energy devices to controllably designing 3D sea-urchin-like CoN-Gr with high water splitting efficiency. Therefore, it could further promote the efficient utilization of valuable Co element in various energy devices.

coredata.dc:title: Recycling valuable cobalt from spent lithium ion batteries for controllably designing a novel sea-urchin-like cobalt nitride-graphene hybrid catalyst: Towards efficient overall water splitting
